--- title: 'A primer on Mixed-Effects Models: Theory and practice' description: "Slides from a tutorial on mixed-effects models I presented to my research group." date: 2020-03-31 images: laces.jpg echo: false message: false warning: false toc: true --- ![](laces.jpg) When I started my PhD I had to get familiar with **Linear Mixed Models** very well very quickly. Then I was asked to present what I learnt and prepare this informal tutorial for my colleagues, which I presented on March 10th, 2020 (yes, early pandemic :confounded:). This post shares the result. This is not supposed to be taken as a formal guide to linear mixed-effects models, but rather as a semi-coherent compilation of notes and self-suggestions that I considered worth sharing with my lab mates during my early stages of in the PhD. Here are the [slides](https://gongcastro.github.io/2020-03-31_linear-mixed-models/#1): ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

Before the presentation I tweeted one of the animations I generated for it.
